page.title: 18 THE RAILWAYS cont.
page.content: This lasted until 1926 when it became the L.M.S. & L.N.E. joint controlled from Lynn. The M.&G.N.J. was known by locals as the 'Muddle and Get Nowhere Railway'. It was nationalised in 1948 and closed to passengers in 1959. The line continued to operate until 1965 as a goods line hauled by diesel locomotives. Some buildings still remain and odd sections of line including the turntable. Toll houses remain as private houses. A second bridge was built when the line was extended. It had to cope with heavy locomotives, operated by hydraulic power. Tolls were charged until 1903. My great great grandad, Harry Crowson started as a lamp boy at 13 and became the longest serving railwayman for M.&G.N.J. Railway. He served for 52 years.
